div1.p: [Carter] supplies additional references she has tracked down for the History of Yellow Fever regarding early epidemics that may have been yellow fever.

October 17, 1928.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
1: Went to see Dr. L. O. Howard last Monday re Goeldi et al
(see enclosed list). He was very kind and cordial, but had no personal
recollection of any of my unverified references and turned me over to
his Librarian, with whom I worked the remainder of the day. Went over
“Os mosquitos no Pará” again, & everything toof John R. Taylor's I could
get (from Howard's personal file,) I'd seen the rest at the S. G.'s
Library) indeed tried everything on my list, but without success. I
am, however, enclosing the “nearest I could find” to Father's statements
from both Goeldi and Taylor. Perhaps Goeldi's will do, though I didn't
think so when I went over it before. Mr. Van Wesep (Information, R. F.)
also sent me this ref. and one other as the best he could do with Goeldi.

2: I have also written, and sent lists, (a) to J. W. W. Stevens and
(b) Morley. See enclosures.

3: Re Ross, Sir Ronald (i.p. 20 and ii. p. 70) can't find statement
re cases reported W. Africa as y. f. probably severe malaria,
and agree with you that, unless found in print it had far better be left
be left out. Indeed, I think it would be better to do so anyway even
if we had found it, for he certainly would not enjoy being quoted to
theat effect mentioned in Father's MS. By the way, I hear that Boyce
(Trans. Soc. trop. med & hygiene 1910-11. p. 38) states that light y. f.
has been attributed to malaria in W. Africa. Haven't had a chance to
verify it, however. Will do so, if you wish to have a “Britisher” agree-
ing with Guiteras.

4:Re Arejula (ii. 51-52) Can't we cut out the literal quotations,
just leaving the statement that he is “just bold enough to differentiate
between peste: epidemia and contagio?” As you saw, the book is abominably
involved and I've put a lot of time on it already. Moreover its merely
a curiosity, not essential to anything. I do wish I could find the
the
-2-
wretchéd quotations, and hardly believe that I could have missed them
had they been in the vol. cited.

4) Enclosed is a real [unclear]:satisfaction: Pym, Sir Wm. (1815) ii. p. 87 Father's
MSS. Father apparently used the 1848 edition for every other quotation
(we have his notes on it) and got thisthe one, re venesection, from the 1815 ed. via La Roche (v.i. p. 468)
as did we. Of course, we had tried the other editions previously, but
had concentrated on that for 1848.

5) ii. p. 79 ) Espinosa, Alonso de (1594) Eng. ed. (1907): author of
ii. p. 80 ) the two quotations on the enclosed white card, ofichose
origin we were uncertain. Father must have used the
Eng. ed (1907), for which you already have library card
and verified quotation re the woman calling the Span.
6 and telling them to enter the land (ii. p. 79).

6) Benzoni, Girolamo, Girolamo (1565) o.k.O. K.[unclear] save for date of his being in going to
Yucatan (iii. i, 52 and iii.i.61) Eng. ed. Hakluyt Soc (1857) p.i.:says:
“hearing of those countries...called...the New World I determined
to go there. In the year 1541...I started from Milan. ”He could
not then have been in “Yucatan in 1539 and /40.” The original ed.,
which we used, is in the Rare Book Room, L. of C. and guaranteed
to put one's eyes out, if Drake or Bernal Diaz doesn't do it first!
Ramusio is pretty bad too. Printing at least has improved in a
not-altogether-evoluting-world!

7) I think you'll find Lancisi (1717) iii.ii.113 satisfactory, tho', as
[unclear] in Alice in Wonderland we've got the statement re time mal-
aria is contracted “contrariwise.”

7) “Page” See Section (iii,i. 106(f. n.) is hopeless. We've tried Page-Paget and cross-
indices and everything else we could think of. “No can do!”

8): Faria e Sousa, Manuel de (1698) (iii,ii.33) Carter's ref. this page
is to wrong book. It should be the History of Portugal not
Africa portuguesa. Also, Barbot's ref. is to Eng. ed. p. 304. The
original ed. seems quite different--with nothing on p. 304 re
those wretchéd Jews.

10) Two library cards re Busto y Blanco, F., quoted by Le Roy de Meri-
court. No.1 No.i is considered better form as a library entry and,
if you like it, other similar library cards should be made to con-
form --i. e. “Yglesias y Pardo, Ferrol 1874” quoted by Beranger-
Feraud, Rey, H (1878) etc.

11) Tentative library card for “Yglesias y Pardo Ferrol, 1874, p.12.”
(iii,i. p. 5) re infection Fernando-Po
1866 by Rosa del Turia, leaving Havana (Aug. 12 , Beranger-Feraud. p.142)
Aug. 2 1866, according to Doctor H. Rey, analyzing and commenting upon
the “Iglesias y Pardo, Luis, Observationes teorico-practicas sobre las
fievres africanas de Fernando Póo, precidadas de una reseña historico-
geographica de la isla Ferrol. In-8. 1877. This in Arch
Med. Nanvale. 29, 1848. 401-409

Po (Oct. 3, 1866. B.-Feraud p. 142 gives “166 criminels deportés”: Rey (p. 407)
“près de 200 criminels déportéś.”

Rey, H (1878) op cit. p. 401-409:..Contributions a la géographie médi-
cale.
L'ile de Fernande-Po. Dr Luis Iglesias y Pardo etc.

p. 407: “La fièvre jaune épidémique a sévèrement éprouvé, et à plusieurs
reprises, la colonie espagnole. En 1812, il y avait sur rade, trois
navires: la goelette Caridad, la frégate Isabel et un ponton, la Perla.
De ces trois équipages 41 hommes et, dans le nombre, le médicin du ponton
sont emportes par cette fièvre. Or, au mois d'aout de cette meme année
etait arrivé à Fernando-Po le vapeur Ferrolapartirti le 10 juin de la Havane,
avec 200 noirs congos emancipés. En 1866, le 3 octobre, le navire
de commerce Rosa del Turia, parti de la Havane le 2 aout, débarque près
de 200 criminels déportés. Une nouvelle épidémie de fiévre jaune éclate à
Fernando-Po; elle fut décorée, il est vrai, du nom de fièvre bilieuse per
nicieuse.”.....

I'm giving the above quotation because the name of the ship, Ferrol
seemed, before reading Rey's article, to have some bearing on the ref.
(iii,i, 105) to Yglesias y Pardo, Ferrol, 1874. You note, however, that
there a lot of ships mentioned here and that it would be quite natural
to find a ship of that name, sailing from tahtthat Spanish port. Also the
word “Ferrol” is added to Yglesias y Pardo in mentioning infections
carried by other ships, as our aforesaid “Rosa del Turia.” Dr. Martell,
of the Library of Congress, to whom we carried all our findings on the
subject says that he thinks the word “Ferrol” refers to the place of
publication of the book and that the title of Iglesias y Pardo's book,
ends with “una reseha historico-geographica de la isla.” Said “isla” be-
ing Fernando-Po. Of course the date given by Rey. H. for IIglesias'
[unclear] vs 1874 (Beranger-Feraud and Augustin), but there may ha
have
-4-
been an earlier edition, or they may have been wrong. At any rate,
I don't believe either of them knew what the word “Ferrol” meant and neither
did we, for that matter! I really think we have it now. At any rate
it is “herewith respectfully referred.”

Heigho! Jack, I wish I had time to write you nice short letters
with everything in them that my long ones contain! It does take time,
however, to make things both clear and concise and I know you'd rather
get a diffuse communication and have me go back to work on references
than spare you a little “wading” through unnecessary remarks “such as the
heathens use!”
I do hope you're getting some goldf these beautiful afternoons.
div1.closer:
With love to you all,
Most truly yours Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.

larva da Stegomyia fasciata, vive ella em buracos, pocos, depresõoes
do solo, etc., contendendo agua relativamente limpa.” i. e.
“So far as is known at this hour concerning the Stegomyia
fasciata, it lives in pools, wells, depressions of the (in the) earth
etc. containing water relatively clear.
(op. cit) pp. 28-9: Stegomyia...prefere mais a agua rela-
tivamente limpa, como costuma ser encontrada em depressões de calhas
horizontaes de chuva nas casas, em barris, quintos, caldedeirões nos
quintaes, no coracão das folhas ainda enroscadas das bananeiras, de
bromelias, etc.
“Stegomyia...prefers water relatively pure, as is usually found
in the depressions of the horizontal rain gutters of houses, in barrels,
tanks, in the heart of the leaves yet folded of the bananas, of
Bromelias etc.”
Don't think much of either of the above, however, the one from
p. 15 might do. Que le parece?

Reoccasional occurrence aegypti larvae in “street gutters
and even pools in the street.”
Reprint from La“Observations on the mosquitos of Havana, Cuba.”

June 1903.”
(op. cit) p. 5-7: “Stegomyia fasciata. Theobald.
“Breeding places.
“Prefers to breed in still water such as is found in rain barrels,
(a) tanks, water pitchers in rooms, in fact will deposit its eggs in any
receptacle containing water. We have also found them in small pools
made by the rain.”
Taylor also mentions (p. 8): “Prefers small artificial collections of water
such as are found in rain-water barrels, water tanks...in fact any recep-
tacle containing water of not too great depth. Also breed in slow
(b) running streams and at the margins of rivers if free from fish.” (News to
me, LAC)
As you see, I had to get this re Taylor from one of Dr. Howard's reprints, as
they didn't have the Revista at the Beurea Bureau of Entomology. If you
wish the first quotation, we can try for it at the S. G.'s Library. Couldn't
get it before. I think Taylor (a) is pretty good, even if he did not re-
fer specifically to pools in streets, don't you?
